dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detroit's skyscrapers shoot up on the horizon. Quicho’s t miles from Detroit, but it might as well be a hundred. Quicho's got it all: freezing weather, a closed down stee mill, and a diner that advertises a burnt cup of Maxwell House as "The World's Greatest Coffee." If Dr. Kevorkian took towns as patients, Quicho would be at the top of h list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A police truck stops in front of the bank. Chief MARTY WA hops out of the truck and walks over to the bank. Checks make sure that the doors are locked. Marty's in his mid 30's. He'd be a good-looking guy if he followed through on his perennial New Year resolutions to switch to light beer and eat less red meat. He walks across the street to the Post Office. Checks the doors. Locked up tight. Marty climbs back into his truck. Si

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty walks up to the front door. The store's closed. He pulls out a large key-ring, shuffles through the keys. Finds the one he wants. Opens up the store. Walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty walks through the dark store. He grabs a six-pack o Bud out of a cooler. Walks over to the cash register. Doe a double-take at the porn magazines. Picks up a "Playboy. Flips through the pages for a quick beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (off centerfold) Nineteen eighty-one? Jesus, I'm getting old. Marty tosses it back on the rack. Then he throws a $5 bil and a note that reads, "6er of Bud -- Marty" on the cash register.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The station is small. It's made up of a large bullpen are Quicho's single jail cell, and Marty's office, which look out on the bullpen. Marty lays on the cot in the cell, watching "Sportscenter TV as he sips a Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: phene rings. Marty pulls himself up, reaches between bars and answers it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Chief Walsh.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Chief, it's Ann Harrison. Somebody broke into my house.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I'll be right over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty walks up the walkway to a small house. Before he ge there, the door opens. ANN HARRISON stands in the doorway wearing just an oversized t-shirt. Ann is beautiful -- especially by Quicho's standards. She Marty's age, but even if he kept up his New Years's resolutions she'd probably be out of his league. If Ann's face couldn't launch a thousand ships, it could get at le a couple hundred out of the harbor. Marty takes a long, less than professional, look at Ann a walks into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A modest house. A lot of things are still boxed up. Can't tell whether Ann is moving in or moving out.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Did you get a look at him, Ann?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Yeah. He's about your height, your weight. Come to think of it, he kinda looked like you.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: So he was good looking.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: No. : Marty stares at her for a beat. She stares right back. A smile escapes from her full lips.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Sorry. Just not my type.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Well, bony dyed blondes aren't my type.  What?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: {out loud) So -- this ugly man -- do you know how he got in the house?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: The bedroom window. Marty follows her into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Marty checks the windows. They're all locked now.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Why don't you tell me what happened? .

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Okay... Ann jumps in bed, pretends to be asleep.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: I was asleep. But then I woke up, 'cause I felt the cold. I saw the window was open. Then I saw him. He was standing right where you are.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Right here? (she nods) Then what'd he do?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: He came toward me... Marty comes closer to her.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Like this?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Then he grabbed me. Marty grabs her arms. Pins her to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he was much stronger than you. (beat) Then he forced himself on top of me.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Like this?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (nods) Uh-huh. And his breath reeked. Kinda like yours.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Then what happened? — ANN He kissed me. Marty kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Then he stripped me naked. Marty starts to pull Ann's shirt over her head as he continues to kiss her. Ann starts to moan.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I was confused. He ripped my shirt off. Marty rips her shirt down the middle, exposing her breast He licks at her breasts, teasing them with his tongue. An moans in pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You didn't put up much of a fight.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Oh, really? Ann flips Marty over so that she's on top of him. She fumbles with his belt, kicks his pants off of him. She ri open his shirt -- the buttons fly off. In seconds, they'r both naked. Ann straddles Marty.... grinds her hips into him... She arches her back, pushes her breasts into his face... He p her closer to him... Pushes deeper inside of her... The bed starts to shake. The springs squeak. Sweat begins to pour off of them as they claw at each other.  ut They groan leuder, both racing toward climax. As they mov together in perfect rhythm we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty and Ann lay in bed, both spent and wearing expressi of contentment.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Did I tell you how glad I am that you moved back here?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Well, that makes one of us.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Come on, Quicho's not that bad. She gives him a look as if to say, "who you kidding?"

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (laughs) Alright, it's awful. But it's a lot better with you here. Marty's cell phone rings. He starts to get out of bed, bu is jerked back -- his right hand is handcuffed to the headboard.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Can you get that, babe? Ann hops out of the bed and looks around Marty's discarde clothes until she finds the cell phone. She tosses it to Marty.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Chief Walsh. Marty listens for a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I'm on my way. Marty hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (to Ann) Jay Guiney just tore up the Crowbar again. I gotta put him in the tank.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: I don't think you're going anywhere.  Oy She smiles and holds up the keys to the handcuffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty, in his button-less police shirt, walks down the street, waving and talking to people. e stops ata newspaper machine. Puts his quarter and grabs a paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty is parked along a country highway, a radar gun stic out his window. Marty is reading the newspaper that he bought. The lead story reads: "Sarcetti Found Guilty." A picture of Marty testifying in court is tucked under the headline. A Ford Escort whips past Marty. The gun reads 70 MPH. Mar starts up the truck, hits the sirens. Pulls out after the Escort. The Escort pulls over. Marty stops his truck. Jumps out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty walks up to the Escort. The DRIVER flashes a cocky smile at Marty. It's clear that there is no love lost between these two.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Problem, Chief?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You were speeding. The driver is CHRIS HARRISON, Quicho's 1985 Homecoming Ki Chris is built like a brick shit-house, still waiting for that day when they let 35 year old has-beens suit up for their high school football team.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (DRIVER)
dialogues.text: C'mon. You're not gonna write me a ticket for that.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Chris, see, since you left town, things have changed a little. We actually made a new law -- now speed limits apply to former high school quarterbacks as well as everybody else. The unseen passenger laughs. And we recognize that laugh. it's Ann. But instead of Marty flipping out at seeing his lover in another man's car, Marty barely even looks at An

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, we're late for Ann's doctor's appointment.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (real concern) Everything all right?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (leans forward) I'm fine, Marty. Chris pats Ann’s knee. Ann moves her leg so that Chris’ h falls off. Marty rips up the ticket.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I'm gonna let you off with a warning. Consider it your welcome home present, Chris.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Fuck you. MARTY — What?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I said, "thanks."

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You should put your seatbelt on, Ann. (beat) Chris, you can keep yours off.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (smiles) Thanks. Marty tips his hat and walks back toward his car. As Mart walks back to his truck, he lowers his mask. It kills him that Ann is married to Chris. In the b.g. Chris peels back onto the highway. By the tim he's out of sight, he's going faster than when Marty pull him over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty pulls up. A beat-up Mazda RX-7 is parked in Marty's clearly marked parking spot. Marty turns into another spa but makes sure that he leaves a nice dent on the Mazda's bumper.  eo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty walks in, carrying the radar gun. TONY DALTEN, Marty's second in command (and Quicho's only other. full time cop), sits at his desk. Tony's at the ag where he's more concerned about fighting acne than fighti crime.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Hey, T. Chae here?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (nods) Bathroom. Dr. CHAE YI walks out of the bathroom, a newspaper tucked under his arm. He's the county coroner and Marty's best friend. - Chae is an Asian man who could be anywhere from 30 to 60. His steady diet of nicotine and alcohol have virtually guaranteed that he'll be on the receiving end of an autop in the next couple of years. He walks over to Marty, wipes his wet hands on Marty's sh

dialogues.speaker: CHAE
dialogues.text: You need paper towels.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (gestures to parking lot) Maybe I'll buy ‘em with the money I get from your parking ticket. Marty walks into his office, Chae on his heels. Chae holds up the newspaper with Marty's picture on it.

dialogues.speaker: CHAE
dialogues.text: I thought the camera only added ten pounds.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I was wondering how long it was going to take you to bring that up.

dialogues.speaker: CHAE
dialogues.text: Maybe now is a good time to revisit my offer to invest the money --~-

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: "Investing?" I always thought it was called "misappropriation of funds."  w

dialogues.speaker: CHAE
dialogues.text: Seven hundred grand in a stock fund, figure ten percent return over a year. Dean could set it up.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You mean Dean could launder it.

dialogues.speaker: CHAE
dialogues.text: You say "to-mato", I say "tom-ato."

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (deadpan) Let's call the whole thing off.

dialogues.speaker: CHAE
dialogues.text: This could be our seed money.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (laughing) You two still going to Costa Rica to open that fishing business?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (taps his watch) T, it's almost two-thirty. Tony nods glumly as he grabs a crossing guard sash anda handheld stop sign off the wall. He checks his gun to mak sure it's loaded.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Make sure you shoot to kill out there. Tony leaves.

dialogues.speaker: CHAE
dialogues.text: I spoke to my buddy who runs the charter business there--

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: "Buddy?" You met him in a chat room. Marty goes to a wall-size safe. Marty dials the combo, th unlocks it with a key. He opens the safe, walks in. Chae follows behind him. The safe is the evidence locker.

dialogues.speaker: EVIDENCE LOCKER
dialogues.text: The evidence locker is sparsely filled with a collection guns, knives, and other odd pieces of evidence. But Chae not interested in any of that. He is looking at a large evidence bag of $100 bills. The bag is marked, "Sarcetti case - No. 23432."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know it's very tough to extradite from Costa Rica. Marty ignores him, puts the radar gun on a shelf.

dialogues.speaker: CHAE
dialogues.text: What the hell they gonna do with the money anyway? Print up some "Just Say No" bumper stickers.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: f£ they do, I'll make sure you get a whole bunch. Marty pushes Chae out of the evidence safe. Locks it.

dialogues.speaker: CHAE
dialogues.text: (defeated) Ten years we've been talking about this. About getting out of here. Chae's cell phone rings. He answers it, listens for a bea then hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: CHAE,
dialogues.text: Shit. What kind of prick dies this late on a Friday afternoon before a three day weekend?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: The nerve of some people. Chae walks out of the station. Marty sits down at his des Chae walks back in.

dialogues.speaker: CHAE
dialogues.text: Hey. Marty looks up to see Chae giving him the finger.

dialogues.speaker: CHAE
dialogues.text: Thanks for the dent, asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty sits on a tired couch, talking on the phone and loo at his Palm VII.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hey, T. It's me. How's everything at the office?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Uh, good, good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great, great. Then I just have one question for you? Why the hell are you at the god damn diner! MARTY!'S PALM: The GPS (Global Positioning System) module activated. He's looking at a map of Quicho. Tony is represented by a blinking blip on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Shit! Knock-knock. Marty looks up. Ann walks in.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Get your ass back there, T. Marty hangs up, then walks over to Ann. She looks trouble

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Can you take a ride with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty and Ann drive into Detroit. The skyscrapers tower around them. They drive in silence. Marty starts to say something, but stops himself. They pull into a hospital parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (nervous) Annie. What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty and Ann walk toward the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Can you walk a little behind me? This is Chris's hospital.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: He's working now?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: No, I'm just worried about his friends. Ann walks into the hospital. Marty waits a beat and then follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann talks to a nurse. Marty hangs back. He noticés a sig above the nurses' station: Oncology Department.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Shit. Ann comes back out. Marty follows Ann downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's almost empty. Ann and Marty walk into...

dialogues.speaker: DR. FRIELAND'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: A small, cramped office. Furniture and files are scattere everywhere. ivy League diplomas dominate the walls. DR. FRIELAND looks up when they enter the room. Frieland is i his mid 30s. And he seems very nervous. He plays with a bronze letter opener, turning it in his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FRIELAND
dialogues.text: Ann.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Hi, Bob. They hug.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (re: office) Who'd you piss off?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FRIELAND
dialogues.text: (forces a laugh) They've got me down here in the dungeon while they fix up my office.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: {re: Marty) This is my brother Marty. Marty and Dr. Frieland shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FRIELAND
dialogues.text: Bob Frieland. (gestures to seats) Please. Ann and Marty sit down. Frieland pulls a file off his des studies it. Starts to say something and then stops. Goes back to the file.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FRIELAND
dialogues.text: Ann. I'm afraid, well, ah... there's been a bit of a setback...  Marty looks at Ann. But she doesn't meet his eyes. She steels herself. Whatever Frieland is about to say, she's been expecting it.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: So this visit isn't just to pad your bill?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FRIELAND
dialogues.text: (weak smile) I'm, uh, afraid not. (beat / refers to charts) The cancer's not in remission. In fact, it's come back very aggressively. It's attacked your liver and lungs... Marty looks worse than Ann. He's devastated. Watching as his world comes crashing down.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: How long?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FRIELAND
dialogues.text: Well, that's difficult--

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Come on, Bob. What'd we agree to when I first came to you?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FRIELAND
dialogues.text: (smiles) No bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: So... A long, tortured beat of silence. Dr. Frieland spins the letter opener in his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FRIELAND
dialogues.text: (pains him) Six months... Ann shakes her head, refuses to believe it.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: But I feel fine--

dialogues.speaker: DR. FRIELAND
dialogues.text: And you will... for a little while longer. Ann reaches out, grabs Marty's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to smile} Next time, give me the bullshit, Doc. Frieland goes over to her, puts a hand on her arm.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FRIELAND
dialogues.text: Ann, there's a counselor here at the hospital I'd like you to see. She's, uh, she's... very good. But Ann's no longer listening. She stares out the window. Marty tries to console her, but she doesn't respond. After a beat, Ann stands up, extends her hand to Dr. Frie

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Thanks for staying so late to see me, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FRIELAND
dialogues.text: Ann... This is not--

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: I appreciate everything you've done for me. I really do. {turns to Marty) Can we go now?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FRIELAND
dialogues.text: Ann, please--

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (to Marty) I'd like to go.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Wait a second. Ann turns and leaves. Marty turns to Frieland.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: There's gotta be something-- Frieland shakes his head slowly -- this is the toughest p of his job.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What about different doctors?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FRIELAND
dialogues.text: She's been to New York, to the Mayo Clinic--  us

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What about experimental treatments? You know, that stuff you see on "60 Minutes?"... A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FRIELAND
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) I'm so sorry. Marty stands there, absorbing it. He drops his chin to hi chest, takes a deep breath. Dr. Frieland puts his arm on Marty's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Doctor. Marty stumbles out of the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann leans against her car. Her tough facade has crumbled. She's bawling. Marty runs up to her. He's crying, too. He buries her head in his chest as she cries even louder.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (after a beat) I locked the keys in the car. After a beat, they both start laughing their tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty drives in silence. Ann stares out the window. Marty keeps stealing glances at her. His heart is breaking. She catches him looking at her. She takes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell me, Annie?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Because when I was with you, I forgot about it. For a couple of hours, I didn't think about dying. I just, I... You made me feel good. She squeezes his hand. They pass a sign that reads, "Entering Quicho."

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: This why you came back?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: No. We came back because we lost our house.  ov

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Chris's gambling?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (nods) And since I couldn't sell my mom's house, I figured we might as well live in it. So, I was born in this shitty town and now I'm gonna die in this shitty town.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Don't say that.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: What? This place is shitty.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter if I say it or not. (resigned) I'm dying.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: We'll go to other doctors--

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (laughs) I've been to ten doctors in three states, Marty. And the only thing that changes is the magazines in the waiting rooms. She stares out the window. He reaches over and grabs her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They lie in bed, both lost in their own thoughts. After a beat, Marty leans over and kisses Ann's forehead. Pulls h closer to him. She kisses his chest.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Let's leave.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You said you didn't want to die here. Well, let's leave.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: And go where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wherever you want. The Caribbean, Europe... Ann kisses him softly. She's touched by the gesture, but knows that it's not realistic.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Should we take your millions or mine?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: We'll figure out the money.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Well, it won't take us long to figure it out since your ex-wife gets most of your money and Chris bet all ours on losing football teams. Ann pulls his face to hers. Kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (beat) Marty, I can't leave with you. I mean, this, this is great, but it's not real.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Not real? Ann, I've been in love with you since we were in first grade.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (smiles) Mrs. Green's class, right? Ann pulls herself up in bed, clutching the sheet to her. grabs her panties and pulls them on. Stands up and starts get dressed.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Where you going?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: I don’t think we should do this anymore.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: It wasn't right for me to drag you into this. Marty swings out of bed, grabs her arms.  o

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: "Drag me into this?" Are you kidding? This past month has been the best month of my life. Hell, this month has been better than most of my years.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Marty, I'm dying...

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I don't care if you have six months or six minutes left. I just wanna be there for all of them. She gently takes his hands off her arm. Kisses him. Looks into his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: You know when you take off a band- aid.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (confused) What?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: It's always better to pull it off quickly. [It might be painful, but it's better than peeling it off slowly.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (starts laughing) That is the worst example I've ever heard. Ann starts laughing, too. But she catches herself.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Marty. I'm so sorry. She kisses him again. Turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I'm tough. I can take the pain of peeling it back slowly.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: I'm the one wearing the band-aid. She turns, heads for the door. Fights every urge to turn back to him. By the time she reaches the door, the tears have already started falling. Marty watches as she disappears out the door. Continues stare even after he hears her car start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty walks out of his apartment. Jumps into his truck. A Post-It note is stuck to the steering wheel -- "I'm sorry Love, A". He stares at the note for a beat, then tosses i to the cluttered floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty fills out a card, attaches it to a bouquet of flowe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty drives an ELDERLY LADY home with her groceries. She BLABS on, but Marty's not listening. All he can think abo is Ann.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann, dressed in a hygienist's uniform, talks with DR. SNY the dentist who owns the practice.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SNYDER
dialogues.text: Well, obviously your health is the most important consideration. A DELIVERYMAN brings in a large bouquet of flowers. Gives to Ann. Ann carries it over to her cubicle. NIKKI, a gum- popping hygienist, comes over to check out the haul.

dialogues.speaker: NIKKI
dialogues.text: Oooh... nice. Lemme see. Ann turns away, opens the card. CARD: A band-aid is taped to the card. "Pull slowly” is written on it. : As hard as she fights it, a smile creeps out of Ann's mou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty flips through his high school yearbook. They might well have subtitled it, “A photo history of Ann & Chris's senior year." They're in nearly every photo. Football captain... Head Cheerleader... Homecoming King and Queen. Marty flips to Ann's senior photo. ANN'S SENIOR PHOTO: She's radiant. Under, "Plans for the future", she's written, "Leave Quicho the day after graduation." Marty's cell phone rings. He jumps up, grabs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He listens for a beat, then tears out of the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty walks into the house.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Annie...

dialogues.speaker: K
dialogues.text: No response. Marty follows the DRONING of a TV. Finds in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: She notices Marty, gives him a weak smile. She looks bad: thinner, dark circles under her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ANN _
dialogues.text: I think he combined the "Death do us part" and the "For richer or poorer"... She hands him a pile of papers. It's an insurance policy. INSURANCE POLICY: Scanning over all the legal mumbo-jumbo Certain things jump out at us... INSURED: Ann Harrison... BENEFICIARY: Chris Harrison. But it's the amount that causes the record to SCREECH to halt in Marty's head: §$1,000,000.00.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: I just found it. It was locked in his desk. Marty continues reading the insurance policy. Ann gets up starts pacing. Her self-pity morphing into anger.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You didn't know about this?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) I remember signing some things, but he told me it was about health insurance.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: {reading policy) He just took this out six months ago...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. My cancer probably saved me from a "fall" in the shower. God, it's so typical of him, too. (bitter laugh) How many dental hygienists do you think are insured for a million dollars? Ann stops pacing, starts crying. She laughs to cover her ing. Marty kisses the top of har head. She looks up at

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something? Were you serious when you said you would leave with me? Marty nods. He was never more serious about anything in h life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris's car pulls in the driveway. He gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann hears the front door open. She panics. Pushes Marty towards the back door. He resists.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (holds up the insurance policy) We're gonna have this out. Right now.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: If we're gonna leave, he can't know. He can't know. (beat) Please... After a beat, Marty gives in, leaves out the back door. She shuts the door just as Chris walks into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Bee

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Hi, I, uh, was going to take the trash out.  She walks over to the garbage can.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: I, uh, thought you were working a double tonight. Chris walks over to the door, looks outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty's just out of Chris' view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris opens the garbage can. It's only a quarter full. Chris moves in close to Ann, forcing her into a corner.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: How was-your appointment yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Appointment ?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: With Dr. Frieland. What? I, ah, didn't see--

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Jay saw you going into his office. Said you were going in with another guy.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: No, no... I stopped by. I, ah, had some questions. But I, I was by myself. Chris grabs her arms, shakes her.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: How can I help you, Annie, if you're not honest with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTY'S POV: Chris pushes Ann against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Don't lie to me! MARTY: Trying to decide what to do. He runs around the house, goes to the front door. Rings t doorbell. After a beat, Chris answers the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Howya doing, Chris?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Chief.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: {gestures to their neighbor's house) Judy Anderson said she saw a prowler outside her place. You happen to see anything? (Chris shakes his head 'no') What about Ann? She home?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: She didn't see anything.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (laughs) You didn't ask her.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: She didn't say anything about it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Maybe I should ask her, you know. Not that I don‘t trust your mind reading abilities or anything. Ann comes to the door. She and Marty share a quick look. Marty looks her over, makes sure that Chris didn't hit he

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: I didn't see anything. Marty waits a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: All right. G'night then. (starts away) I'm just gonna be checking out the woods. If you see something, gimme a holler. Chris shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty's in his truck, watching Ann's house through a set binoculars. The lights go off in the house. Marty starts his truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Sam Adams or Heineken served here. Marty sits at by himself, finishing up a Bud. Chris walks in. Mar stares at him for a beat, then turns back to the basketba highlights on TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris. walks over to the bar and sits next to Marty.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (re: TV, shakes head) Pistons. I come back after ten years and they still suck. Marty shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Let me get you a refill there.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I'm all set.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: C'mon, it ain't a bribe. Chris gestures for two beers to the bartender.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Lemme ask you something. Tonight, when you were looking for that prowler, did you see anybody else out there? (Marty shakes his head) Nobody leaving my place?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: No, why?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I don't know why I'm even telling you this. (looks Marty straight in the eye) I had a feeling last night when I came home that Ann was with some other guy. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah, and I think he snuck out the back when I got home.  to ut

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (pretends to think) Didn't see anybody. @ (beat) What'd Ann say?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: That I was crazy. She said she was just taking out the trash.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Maybe the garbage was full.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (laughs) In the fifteen years we've been married I can count the number of times she took out the garbage on my thumb.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I didn't see anything. Chris nods to himself.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Thanks, anyways. @ The bartender brings their two Buds. Chris takes a long of his beer.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I tell you, though, next time that little pussy comes around I'll be waiting.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: "Little pussy?"

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Sure, he scurried out the back door the second he heard my voice. I mean, I could almost respect a guy who had the balls to confront me, to tell me, “Yeah, I'm fucking your wife." Right? (Marty shrugs) Like that guy who was fucking Amy. I mean, shit, that had to kill you, that your wife's fucking some guy. But still, I mean, you gotta respect that guy a little, right? @ Chris smiles at Marty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe Ann is fucking somebody. Except, that unlike my ex-wife, & your wife won't let this guy tell you that you're a shitty husband and you don't deserve Ann. Maybe there's nothing he'd rather do than walk up to you, look you in your eyes-- (Marty stares into Chris‘ eyes) And say, "Chris, I'm fucking your wife." Is that what you'd want? Chris LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I'd respect him at least. And if he did, I'd look him in the eye-- (stares at Marty) And say, "if you ever come near my wife again, I'll kill you." They stare at each other for a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I think you're telling the wrong @ guy here, Chris. A beat, then Marty taps his gun.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Because as a cop, I can't let you go around making threats on people's lives. If I thought you were serious, I'd be obligated to do something.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Lucky for both of us, I don't think we'll have to find out how serious I am. I think Ann understands where I'm coming from. Marty finishes his beer and stands up.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Thanks for the beer, Chris.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Thanks for listening. e Marty starts for the door, then turns and stops.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Give Ann my best, willya Chris?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty is talking on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Deano, it's Marty. Listen, does your dad still rent his house on the lake?... Really. What's his number? Marty writes the phone number down. His other line rings.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Deano. Gotta run. {picks up second line) Chief Walsh.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: We've got a change of plans...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty and Ann walk down the street, hand-in-hand. Ann's a bundle of nervous energy. They stop in front of a brownstone. Ann checks the marque "The Living Gift."

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: This is it. They walk up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann and Marty are greeted by ROBERT GUILETTE, a tall, impeccably dressed salesman. - Robert was put on this ear do one thing: sell.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Mrs. Harrison. Robert Guilette. A pleasure to meet you. (to Marty) And this must be your husband. Marty gives Ann a quick look. She shrugs, 'go with it.'

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (smiles) Yeah. Chris Harrison. Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty and Ann sit in the dark, watching a slide show.  sy wo rh rh o The pictures CLICK by: A smiling man next to the tower... A woman on a sun-drenched beach... A fam. reunion...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: bt hee

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: These are just some of the people we've helped. Robert turns on the lights. And here's the pitch...

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Ann, a viatical settlement is all about opportunity. About giving you the opportunity to do things that you've only dreamed of, whether that be walking along a deserted beach in Hawaii or running with the Bulls in Pompeii-- — ANN Pamplona. The buils run in Pamplona. The volcano erupted in Pompeii. Robert LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: My point was -- before the geography lesson -- the only limit is your imagination.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: And by how much money you offer me, right?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Someone's done their homework.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Okay, let me make sure I've got this straight. I name you the beneficiary on my life insurance policy--

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Well, not me personally. You name the Living Gift as your beneficiary. After, of course, we purchase your policy from you.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: And you-- I mean, the Living Gift-- collects on the policy when I die.  nw wo

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (nods) As the beneficiary, we collect on 6 the policy after you've passed on, yes. However, I want to take this opportunity to assure you, at the Living Gift maximizing profits is not our objective. Last year our return on investment fell below that of the average mutual fund.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: How much do I get? Robert smiles, waits a beat. Knows he's got her.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: We determine the buyout after your consultation with our medical staff.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: And the amount depends on how long your medical staff says I have to live, right?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: & (laughs) It's dependent on a variety of factors. But yes, life expectancy is one of the many factors we consider.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: How about a ballpark figure?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Now don't quote me on this. But people who are generally in your category--

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: My category?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Those whose life expectancy falls below, ah, your ah, expectancy, ah, six months... the standard payout for this category.is between seventy five and eighty percent of the policy. @ It doesn't take long for Ann to do the math in her head

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Seven hundred and fifty thousand? Robert nods slowly. Ann's trying to temper her enthusias

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Now, if this is something you're interested in, we just have to move quickly.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (smiling) Yes. (beat) Is that quick enough?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You can sleep on it--

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: I don't need to. I -~.I mean my husband and I -- want to do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann and Marty walk out of the office. Well, Ann practical floats out. As soon as they're outside, she jumps into Marty's arms and lets out the loudest scream of joy you'v ever heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris, wearing a security guard uniform, walks out of the employee parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris flips through "Car & Driver" magazine, ocogling the expensive sports cars.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, a Humvee. That's the one... A MORGUE ATTENDANT walks into the office.

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Hey, little help here, Chris. Chris nods and walks out of the security office. Another Attendant stands over a gurney holding a body bag, waitin go into the morgue. Chris unlocks the morgue door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boxes are everywhere. Marty is packing his apartment up. The phone RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. As he listens, his face registers bad news. He runs out t door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty's trying to console Ann. She looks awful -- a mixtu of desperation and anger. Ann starts pacing.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What'd Robert say?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: One of their investors pulled all his money out... they're broke.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: We'll go somewhere else. Have someone else buy your policy.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: I can't go anywhere else. There's only two days left to change the — policy.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: There's some provision in the policy -- the beneficiary can't be changed after six months. And that's in two days--

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: We'll call 'em. There has to be something-- Ann turns on him, channeling all her anger at Marty.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: It's too late! She grabs a glass. Hurls it against the wall. SMASH! Marty tries to touch her, but she shakes him off.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Maybe--

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Don't!

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: There's got to be--  w tw

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: {holds up her hand) Don't. This is not fixable. Marty looks at her for a beat. Then he takes the broom an dustpan out of the closet. Starts cleaning up the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann watches m. But instead of being touched by this small gesture, it pisses her off.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (cold) I don't need you to clean up my messes. Marty continues sweeping. She takes the broom away from h Their eyes lock. She puts the broom in the closet. She turns and walks out the kitchen. Marty watches her go. Then, after a beat, he grabs the br and dustpan. Finishes cleaning up the glass. 0O.s. Ann's peels out of the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty's on the phone. After a beat, Ann's machine picks u Marty hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty locks a DRUNK in the cell. He takes the Drunk's wal into the evidence safe. He lingers for a bit, staring at evidence from the Sarcetti trial -- the $660,000. He pick up a stack of $100 bills. Stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty directs traffic. He catches a glimpse of Ann and Ch down the street. Ann looks awful. The last twenty-four hours have seemingly aged her twenty-four years. Marty tries to make eye contact with her. Just wants some acknowledgement. But he doesn't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty's laying on the cot in the cell, staring blankly at TV. He looks like shit. The front door opens. It's Ann. She smiles weakly at Marty, walks up to the cell. She loo just as bad as Marty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd they lock you up for?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Ignored somebody.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (smiles) I thought that was just misdemeanor? »

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Nope. It's a felony in this town.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Didn't realize the punishment was so stiff. (beat) Do we have to keep talking like this? . Marty smiles, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I just... I just needed some time. She pulls a bundle of papers from her purse, pushes them through the cell bars to Marty. He looks at the papers, t at Ann.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What's this? PAPERS: Ann's insurance policy. Marty's listed as the beneficiary.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: My going away present. Marty stares at the policy for a long beat. He's moved by Ann's gesture.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Buy that fishing boat you and Chae have always been talking about.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You can't--

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Please. (beat) Hey, name the boat after me, okay? Ann doesn't look at Marty as she turns to leave. His hand shoots out of the cell, grabs her arm.  ws Pt

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You can't leave.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: I can't stay here any more. I need some... peace. I talked to a friend who lives in Chicago. I'm going to stay with her--

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You're not going--

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Please, don't make this harder... Marty sticks his hand outside the cell, tries to unlock i but the key is stuck. He jingles the key around.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Can you-help me here? Ann plays with the keys, finally unlocks the cell.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You can't leave.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Marty--

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You wanna know why you can't leave? (beat) ‘Cause we're leaving.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: What? Marty gives her the insurance policy back.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: And you can't give this to me. Marty leads her into his office. He unlocks the evidence safe... walks in. Gestures for Ann to follow.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Because I'm going to buy it from you. Ann stares at the Sarcetti money, shocked. After a beat, plan dawns on her. She starts shaking her head.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: No. I can't-- I won't let you do that .  w ur

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I've worked it all out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A window's been smashed in. Marty and Tony look at the evidence locker. There's crowbar marks all over it. Marty takes the $660,000 out of the safe.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (to Tony) I'm gonna put this in a safe deposit box at the bank... Marty puts the money into a briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty takes the money out of the briefcase, puts it into duffel bag. He shuts the now empty briefcase, locks it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty puts the empty briefcase into a safe deposit box. Locks it. Marty's buddy DEAN, the bank manager, looks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty stares at the $660,000 in the duffel bag for a beat Then he ZIPS the bag up. Heads out.

dialogues.speaker: ANN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: .. So I name you the beneficiary on my life insurance policy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANN'S INSURANCE POLICY: Marty's listed as the beneficiary Marty and Ann watch as a NOTARY PUBLIC stamps the policy, seals it in an envelope and puts it in the mail slot.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: w oy

dialogues.speaker: ANN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: . And when I die, you'll replace the money we took with the money from the insurance company? (END OF MONTAGE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann and Marty sit at the kitchen table, staring at the $660,000 in the duffel bag.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: What if they want it back?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: By law, the money has to stay in the possession of the arresting department for one year from the conclusion of the trial. (beat) It's all yours.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (kisses him) No, it's all ours.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (checks his watch) I better get going. Marty gets up and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Chris still working the graveyard tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (nods) He's on at ten.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Then we'll leave at eleven. Ann walks over, kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: My life starts tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: No, our life starts tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty drinks a beer with Tony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long do you think you're gonna be taking care of your mother?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Not sure, T. Probably five or six months.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Cancer, man...

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: So you ready to be acting Chief or what?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You're gonna do good. Marty stands up. Tony follows. They share a quick embrace MARTY am I'll be in touch. Marty heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Don't let Chae off on those parking tickets.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MARTY'S APARTMENT .- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Marty hangs up the phone. Rubs his face, worried. He glances at his watch -- 11 PM. Starts pacing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty parks down the street from Ann's place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann and Chris's cars are in the driveway. But no lights a on in the house. Marty quietly approaches the house. Marty sneaks around the house, looks in windows -- nobody home. He tries to open the windows. No luck -- they're al locked. Something catches his eye on the ground: an electronic ho key (the ones they magnetically charge) with "Ramada Inn" written across it. He picks it up, looks at it. Pockets i Marty dials Ann‘s number on his cell phone again. It just rings and rings...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ELDERLY WOMAN walks to the window. Looks out. ELDERLY WOMAN'S POV: Marty, standing under a light, tries the back door -- it's locked. She has a perfect view of h Marty looks up. Sees the old woman staring at him. He quickly jumps back into the shadows and heads off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty hurries back to his truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty's looking at the Ramada Inn hotel key.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Yeah. Do you have a guest by the name of Ann Harrison there?... How about a Chris Harrison?... Nothing, huh. Marty hangs up, tosses the key on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty paces his barren apartment as he talks on the cell

dialogues.speaker: MARTY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Yeah, Tone, it's me. You hear of any accidents or anything tonight? He hangs up, dials Ann's number again. Gets the machine. He kicks his suitcase across the room.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Fuuuuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty, half-asleep in a chair, grabs the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (instantly alert) Yeah... WHAT?!

dialogues.speaker: SMASH CUT TO
dialogues.text: ws we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty's truck slams to a stop outside Ann's house. Or mor accurately, what used to be Ann's house... The house is completely burned down. Quicho's rag-tag volunteer fire department finishes watch the house burn. The fire hasn't spread to their neighbor' house. Marty jumps out of his truck, runs up to the smoldering house. He grabs the FIRE CHIEF (Paulie).

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Paulie... where? The Fire Chief leads Marty over to the debris. They stomp through the embers, come up to: TWO CHARRED CORPSES. Burn beyond recognition. MARTY: Turns away from the corpses and PUKES all over the Fire Chief's boots.

dialogues.speaker: FIRE CHIEF
dialogues.text: Jesus, you all right here, Marty?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Yeah... Just...

dialogues.speaker: FIRE CHIEF
dialogues.text: I'll grab ya some coffee. The Fire Chief leaves Marty staring at the corpses. He starts shaking his head slowly. Trying to remain composed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty, devastated, leans against Ann's car, talking with Fire Chief.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: ...The propane tank?

dialogues.speaker: FIRE CHIEF
dialogues.text: (nods) I just woke up Jack. He said Chris called last week saying he wanted his tank looked at, been having some problems with it. Marty nods, walks over to where the corpses lay. He stare numb.

dialogues.speaker: CHAE, (O0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who ordered them weil done?  Fy oO Marty turns, grabs Chae by the collar.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: How about showing a little fucking respect? Marty shoves him to the ground and storms off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty watches as Chae's people load the corpses into a tr Chae walks up, notices how devastated Marty is.

dialogues.speaker: CHAE
dialogues.text: Sorry about that back there. I'm an asshole... Marty waves him off. A van labeled "County Arson Investigation" pulls up to th site. A police car with "Cole County Sheriff's Department painted across it pulls up right behind the arson van. Detective ALEX COLE (early 30s) steps out of the passenge side. Chae stares at her as she makes her way toward them His attentiveness is easy to understand. Even Alex's off- rack pants suit can't hide the fact that she could be mak three times a detective's salary dancing at one of the lo gentlemen's clubs. But the people who can't get past the Playboy figure are usually the worse for it. Especially if they've committed murder. Alex does a double-take when she sees Marty. He recognize her as well.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: That's the kind of greeting I get? She offers her hand. He shakes it limply.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: By the way, you owe me fifty bucks for that room service bill. Marty nods. Too devastated to have any interest in catchi up with Alex. She surveys the scene.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Looks like somebody forgot to listen to Smokey, huh?  Marty doesn't respond. She turns back to him.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Smokey the bear. You know -- "Only you can prevent forest fires." Marty still doesn't respond. Alex waves her hand in front his face.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Bear. Could talk. Anyway...

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Excuse me for a sec. Marty heads off. Alex watches him for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: FIRE CHIEF
dialogues.text: -twaving his hands) Detective. Alex walks over toward the Fire Chief and two ARSON INVESTIGATORS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two Arson Investigators stand with the Fire Chief, sifting through the ashes, talking in HUSHED tones. Marty leans against his truck by himself. Alex WHISTLES at Marty, gestures for him. Reluctantly, he walks over to them.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Smokey wouldn't be happy at all. (beat) This was arson.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's buzzing with activity. And at the center is Alex, barking into her cell phone. Marty stands off to the side The fact that Ann and Chris were murdered has shaken him of his daze.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: That's bullshit! I caught this thing... Tell Yaeger to suck my dick!... Fine, twenty-four hours. Alex snaps her phone shut, goes over to Marty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I've got 'til tomorrow before the Sherriff pulls me for the old boys club on this thing. And if I run this thing out of my office, they're gonna be trying to trip me up. So if it's alright with you, I want to run it out of your place here. Marty considers it a beat. He wants to stay close to the investigation.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Good, I'll have some of my men set up shop at your place. (beat) And why don't I ride back with you. That way we can catch up on old times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty stares out the window, preoccupied. Alex watches hi She notices his Palm on the dashboard. She picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (off Palm) Yep, here's my number. Right where I wrote it. Marty doesn't answer. Alex continues to play with the Pal Opens the GPS application.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Oh, you've got the GPS thing on here. Pretty high-tech for a bunch of hicks.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: We hicks prefer to be called hayseeds.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Oh, so he can speak... She waits for Marty to say something. He doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: +... dust not much. Marty nods his head. Alex laughs and goes back to the Pal  Locate who? -- Tony." A beeping

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PALM: Alex clicks “Lecate." A list pops ur Tony, Ambulance, Fire Truck?". She clicks blip appears on a map of Quicho.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Tony your gay lover?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (laughs) He works for me. (takes the Palm) This thing allows me to track wherever he is. Marty tosses the Palm on the dashboard.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Pretty useless. But Tony's brother sells 'em and he gave us a bunch of 'em so he could use us in the advertising.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (imitating advertising) Local hicks -- I mean hayseeds -- swear by our GPS tracking system. Alex looks at Marty, expecting a laugh. But he doesn't sa anything. His mind is back on Ann's death. Alex notices h despondent and distracted Marty looks.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You seem pretty shaken up by this. You know ‘em well?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (he shrugs) Went to high school with them. They had just moved back here a couple months ago.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: So, any idea who did it? Marty shakes his head -- he truly is at a loss.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: No idea.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: They have any enemies?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: No, nothing like that.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Money troubles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing I heard of.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Either of them fucking around on the side? Marty hesitates for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) No. I always heard they had a perfect marriage.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (scoffs) The perfect marriage? I thought they stopped making those back in the fifties. Marty pulls up to the police station. There's already three sheriff's cars here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex is huddled with Deputy BASTE, her second in command. Baste (40s) is the kind of guy who is actually thankful h doesn't have a sense of humor. When he isn't working as a cop, Baste is at home cleaning his guns and watching "Cop Other DEPUTIES are taking over the office: talking on phones, carrying in evidence.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Marty is oblivious te the activity. He's staring at a pho of he and Ann. It still hasn't quite sunk in.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, lazy bones. Marty hides the photo, spins around in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I'm gonna go by their dentist's Place to pick up dental records. How ‘bout coming along? Marty nods, then gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Snyder (Ann's boss) hands Alex two sets of dental rec Marty stands there, feigning interest.  ae ut

dialogues.speaker: DR. SNYDER
dialogues.text: Here you go. Alex looks over the dental records

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: How long had Ann worked for you?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SNYDER
dialogues.text: About two months. Ever since she and Chris got back into town.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Where's her desk?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SNYDER
dialogues.text: (pointing) It was over there.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: "Was?" -

dialogues.speaker: DR. SNYDER
dialogues.text: She stopped working last week.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: She quit?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SNYDER
dialogues.text: Uh, kind of. (beat, sadly) Ann had terminal cancer.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: She was dying? Dr. Snyder nods. Alex looks to Marty, who pretends to be shocked.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SNYDER
dialogues.text: I think she was trying to keep it quiet.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Bruce, can you think of anybody who would've wanted to kill her? Dr. Snyder thinks for a beat, then shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Is there anything else you can tell us? Weird behavior?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SNYDER
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think she was having an affair. r They all spin around. Nikki (the other hygienist) stand there, chewing gum. Marty eyes Nikki warily.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: She told you she was having an affair?

dialogues.speaker: NIKKI
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) Nah, she wasn't too talkative with me. I mean, we'd talk about stuff, you know like what was happening on our stories and stuff. But I just got that feeling you know, like sometimes when she was on the phone she would... (whispers) Talk real quiet and stuff-- Marty jumps in, not liking where this is going.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: ("skeptical") C'mon. She was whispering? @ That's your proof, Nik?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Any idea who it was?

dialogues.speaker: NIKKI
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) Nah... (snaps her fingers) But he was classy. A couple weeks ago she got this real nice thing of flowers. Remember, Bruce? Dr. Snyder nods. Nikki continues, emboldened.

dialogues.speaker: NIKKI
dialogues.text: And, I, uh, dated Chris back in high school -- when they broke up for a couple of weeks -- and Chris definitely wasn't the type of guy to send flowers. Marty whips out his cell phone. Dials a number.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: e@ Hey, Nancy. It's Marty. Howya doing?... (more)  MARTY (cont'd; INTO PHONE) Listen, uh, somebody sent flowers to Ann Harrison a couple weeks ago. Any idea who it was?... {after a beat, for Nikki's benefit) Chris sent ‘em. Thanks. Before Marty hangs up we hear:

dialogues.speaker: VOICEMAIL LADY
dialogues.text: Dial your password, then press pound-- Marty hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Thanks for all your help, Nik.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex pulls onto a highway on-ramp.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: This isn't the way back.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Snyder gave me the name of Ann's doctor off her insurance forms. I wanna find out about her cancer. Marty shifts uncomfortably. He has no interest in meeting with Ann's doctor.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Well, how 'bout dropping me off then?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What? You don't like hanging around with me unless you've downed six margaritas?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I just don't think both of us need to sit around reading "Highlights" while we wait to talk to her doctor. (be at) Plus, I only had a couple margaritas.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: They were doubles.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You gonna drop me off?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I will if you can tell me why you never called me after the conference.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I apologize.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: That's not a reason. (beat) Well, it's your loss. ‘Cause I usually give it up on the second date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk up to the front desk. Marty looks around, tryin to figure out how to avoid seeing Ann's doctor. He sees someone walk out of the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I gotta hit the head. I'11 meet you in there. Alex shrugs and Marty starts for the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (to receptionist Where's Dr. Donovan's office?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: (checking files) Uh, let's sea... Oh, here it is. Her office--

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (turning around) "Her"?! Alex and the Receptionist shoot Marty a dirty look.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: We can vote now, too, Chief.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: (for Marty's benefit) Her office is on the third floor.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Thanks. Alex starts for the elevators. Marty follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) A liar and a chauvinist. I sure wish I knew that about you before I invited you back to my hotel room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Marty isn't listening. He's still wondering why the h Ann's doctor is a she.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty and Alex sit across from DR. DONOVAN (female, 40s.) Dr. Donovan reads froma file.

dialogues.speaker: DR. DONOVAN
dialogues.text: It says here that Miss Harrison chose me as her internist from the HMO directory, but I've never met her.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: She's never been here for an exam? Dr. Donovan shakes her head. Marty is still trying to fig out why they're talking to this doctor instead of Dr. Fri

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: It just doesn't make any sense -- She was dying of cancer but she never came into your office.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Maybe she saw another doctor here? Dr. Donovan goes over to her computer. Clicks a few butto

dialogues.speaker: DR. DONOVAN
dialogues.text: {off computer) No, she's never been a patient at this hospital. Marty looks like he's going to puke for the second time t

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Marty lurches out of his chair. Throws opens the door. The two women watch him go, surprised by his exit.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Marty staggers out of the office. He steadies himself against the wall. His brain is having a hard time processing what he just h  ur After a beat, Marty runs down the hall. Hits the stairwe

dialogues.speaker: STAIRWELL
dialogues.text: Marty-bounds down the stairs. Takes them four at a time.

dialogues.speaker: BASEMENT
dialogues.text: Marty emerges in the basement. Runs down the hall. Finds Dr. Frieland’s office Throws open the door... The office is completely empty except for a desk and chai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex hurries down the hall as she talks into her cell pho

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Listen, I want you to find out who her doctor is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty walks around the empty office in a daze. Stares at the bare walls that used to hold Ivy League dip Then Marty grabs the chair. Tosses it against the wall. The chair is reduced to firewood. Marty flips the desk over. Starts kicking it. And kicking it. Out of breath, he backs into the wall. Slumps against it. Slides down to the floor. Then something catches his eye on the floor next to the d The letter opener that Dr. Frieland kept fiddling with. Marty picks it up with his fingertips. Turns it over, lets the light catch it... There's fingerprints on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty runs out of the hospital. Jumps into the police car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex taps her fingers on the wheel.  uw he

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You get a check-up or something? Marty pats his stomach.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Bad coffee. Alex shakes her head and starts the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They head into downtown Quiche. Marty stares out the window, catatonic. Ann's betrayal still sinking in. Alex's cell phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Yeah... I don't give a shit. Figure out who I have to blow to get my phone records. _ MARTY: The words "phone records" shake Marty out of his t Knows his number is all over those records.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: listens for a beat) Results, not excuses, Baste. That's what they pay us twenty- five grand for. (listens) We're pulling in now. Alex snaps her cell phone shut.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: God damn phone company's dragging their feet on the phone records. Marty doesn't answer. Alex looks over at him -- he's pale.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (off his expression) That must've been some bad coffee. Alex pulls into the police station parking lot. They hop out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex follows Marty up the stairs. Marty opens the door and walks in.

dialogues.speaker: BULLPEN
dialogues.text: Baste and Tony talk with TWO WOMEN and a MAN.  wy JUDY, ome of the women, turns around, sees Marty and wave

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Hey, Chief. MARTY!S FACE: Pure terror. Marty turns away from Judy, bumping into Alex. The other woman, JUDY'S MOTHER, turns around. Just in time to see the back of Marty's head. Now we realize why Marty turned away... Judy's Mother is the one who saw him at Ann's last night. The man is a SKETCH ARTIST. He finishes his drawing and shows it to Judy's mother.

dialogues.speaker: SKETCH ARTIST
dialogues.text: How's this look, mam? Judy's Mother scrutinizes the sketch (we don't see it.)

dialogues.speaker: BASTE
dialogues.text: (to Alex) We've got an eyewitness here. Alex looks at the sketch. Marty turns to go, keeping his back to Judy's Mother. Alex reaches out and grabs his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Take a look at this. Alex holds out the sketch for Marty. Marty turms around slowly, scratching an “itch" on his fa So that he partially obscures: his face from Judy's Mothe He looks at the sketch. SKETCH: Looks like Marty in a general way. Eighty year old eyes and a hack artist have spared him.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Ring any bells? JUDY'S MOTHER: Watches Marty. She tries to get a good look, but his hand blocks her vie Her synapses firing... where has she seen that face?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Kinda looks like you, Chief.  w ui

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (forced laugh) Yeah, if I was as ugly as you, T. Marty turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Chief, I don't think you've met my mother yet. She just came up from Dearborn. Judy and her mother approach Marty. Marty turns so that Judy’s mother is looking at his profi

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Marty Walsh. Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: Carol Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Thanks for all your help, mam.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Such a shame... They were so young.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Awful. Excuse me, Judy.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: You look very familiar--

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (snaps his fingers) Yes, that's right. I met you at the supermarket last week. Judy's Mother tries to remember... is that it?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: Supermarket?--

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Yes, out in front. It must've been last Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: But mother didn't get in until Thursday. Baste comes over, holding a book of mug shots.

dialogues.speaker: BASTE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Anderson, we need you again.  ut fi Marty seizes the moment to escape. He turns and ducks into his office. Judy's mother turns back to Marty, but he's gone.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY.'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Marty grabs his phone, dials 411.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Yeah, the number for the Living Gift in Detroit. Marty dials the number -- it starts ringing. Marty grabs a newspaper article off his corkboard. It reads, "Police Make Drug Bust -- $660,000 Seized." He reads the date off the article: May 15, 2001.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (off article) May fifteenth.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: The Living Gift.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Yeah, uh, is, uh, Robert there?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Who should I say is calling?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Uh, Chris Harrison.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: One moment, please. Marty digs through his files as he waits.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: This is Robert.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Robert. This is, uh... Chris Harrison. Ann Harrison's husband--

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Of course. How's Ann?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: She's ah... fine. Listen, I, uh, this is a weird question, but did you guys go bankrupt? FILES: Marty pulls out his copy of Ann's insurance policy Technically he's a millionaire today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Bankrupt? If we did, somebody forgot to tell me.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Did, uh, did Ann talk to you after we met?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Of course. She called me with the good news.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: "Good news?"

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Sure. That her doctors believed she was going to make a full recovery... It hangs there for a long beat. Marty scans Ann's policy, finds what he's looking for... The date of inception: May 24th, 2001. Less than a week after Marty made the drug bust.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (sotto, off date) Couldn't even wait a fucking week.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Well, needless to say, I'm very happy for the two of you. It's a miracle.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Yeah. A real fucking miracle. Marty slams the phone down. Alex looks in at him. He smiles, realizes he can’t freak out here.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (calling out) Hey, T. Tony walks into his office. Marty pulls Dr. Frieland's letter opener out of his jacke un ut  wi

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I need you to run this over to the lab in Detroit and have ‘em run the prints.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (points to deputies) Is it for this thing?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. I want you to wait there 'til they're done. And then call me. Alex raps on Marty's door.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: An Agent Stark from the DEA is on line one for you.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Who? —

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Agent Stark. DEA. Says it's about the Sarcetti case.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (long beat) Thanks. Marty stares at the blinking button on the phone. He takes a deep breath, picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: This is Chief Walsh.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT STARK
dialogues.text: Chief Walsh. Agent Stark with the DEA. How you doing?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Busy.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT STARK
dialogues.text: You and I both. Listen, I understand you're holding the evidence from the Sarcetti case.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: {tortured beat) Uh-huh.  Drip... EEEEHHH...

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: a

dialogues.speaker: AGENT STARK
dialogues.text: reat. That means you're my new best friend. Listen, I'm going to send a couple of my agents up from the Detroit office to pick up that cash. We think the money might be linked to one of our investigations. bead of sweat drops on to Marty's desk.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what. How ‘bout I call you tomorrow and we'll figure out a time--

dialogues.speaker: AGENT STARK
dialogues.text: Chief. This had to be done the day before yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. But that evidence has to stay in my possession for a year--

dialogues.speaker: AGENT STARK
dialogues.text: I guess I'm not making myself clear here. This has been a two year ongoing investigation. I have the cooperation of the FRI, the ATF, and two foreign governments... So you'll have to excuse me if I don't give two shits about your rules of evidence. (beat) My men'll be up sometime this aftermoon. Oh, yeah, and Chief?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT STARK
dialogues.text: Have a nice day. Stark hangs up on the other end. Marty holds the phone to his ear for another beat, dazed:

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You okay, boss? Marty nods, then hands Tony the letter opener.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Tell 'em we need this thing quick. (glances at the bullpen) Really quick.  “a w

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (gestures to deputies) Then we should just give it to them- -

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Just do it! Alright!

dialogues.speaker: BULLPEN
dialogues.text: Alex looks in at Marty and Tony, curious about the outbur Baste hurries over to Alex.

dialogues.speaker: BASTE
dialogues.text: I just got off the phone with her doctor -- she's over at Detroit Medical Center. Anyways, she says that she's been Ann's doctor for the past five years. And that as of her last check-up three months ago, Ann was perfectly healthy.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: She didn't have cancer? Baste shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I pretended I was a size four once, but why the hell's someone gonna pretend they had cancer?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (confused by Marty's tone) Sorry. I just thought these guys could do it faster.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: No, no, I'm sorry. Marty puts his arm around Tony's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Just tell 'em we need it fast. Tony nods and goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
